713198f.text:
238-244 and 246 West 44th Street, south side, between Broadway and Eighth Ave., showing the Little Theatre at No. 238-244. Adjoining sam is a 4-story brownstone house that has given way to the present St.
James Theatre; the entrance to same being here.
About 1920.
Mattie Edwards Hewitt Photograph.

717500f-a.text:
The Hotel Claridge, Broadway at the S.E. corner of 44th Street.
Below the Claridge is the Hotel Cadillac.
About 1920.
nift of E. M. Jenks.

723533f-a.text:
Broadway, east side, south from 44th Street, showing also Seventh Avenue, east side, from 44th to 40th Streets. This picture was made on Armistice Day, during the two-minute silence, and shows the Times Square crowds standing hushed, the men with bared heads, as a bugler on a balcony of the Hotel Astor sounds "Taps." Notice the campaign poster on the Hotel Cadillac for Fiorello H. La Guardia, now a member of the House of Representatives. kr La Guardia, the Republican candidate, has just been defeated in the mayoralty election by Mayor James J. Walker, now at the height of his popularity. A year earlier the Republicans had denied renomination to him for the House of Representatives, and he made a successful campaign on the Socialist ticket. Four years later, in 1933, he will be elected Mayor of New York, defeating the incumbent, Mayor John P. O'Brien,
and former Aldermanic President Joseph V. MoKee.
November 11, 1929.
International News.

723529f-a.text:
Broadway, west side, south from and including 44th Street. This view also shows Seventh Ave., west side, south from but r
including 44th Street.
About 1930.
Times Photo Service.

160w158 West 44th Street, at and adjoining the S.E. corner of Broadway. The corner building No. 160, is the Hotel Claridge with its main entrance on

713195f-a.text:
Wost 44th Street, at the N.E. corner of Broadway, showing excavation where the former Criterion and Loew's N.Y. Theatres stood. Aoross clearance is shown Broadway, west side, at West 45th Street, with a portion of the

717502f-a.text:
(1)
Broadway, e st side, north from West 44th Street, and showing exoavation where the former Criterion and Loew's N.Y. Theatre stood. This
view shows Loew's State (motion picture) Theatre entrance thru the 17-story
building, at the N.E. corner of West 45th Street., with the theatre building  at it's rear.
August 9, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
A portion of No. 1, and showing across excavation, the Lyceum
Theatre (Nos. 157-149), with the 45th Street Exchange (Nos. 147-141) adjoining. Note the R.K.O. Building and R.C.A. Tower in the background.
August 9, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
A view westward thru excavation, and showing the west side of Broadway, with the Hotel Astor thereon. 45th Street is in the foreground,
with 44th Street on the left.
August 9, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.

713182f-a.text:
West 44th Street, north side, east from (No. 141-139) a point midway between Broadway and Sixth Ave., and across the latter and showing the Columbia Radio Playhouse (formerly the Hudson Theatre) at No. 141-139; the Hotel Langwell (formerly the Hotel Gerard) at No. 129-23 and the Belasco Cheatre at No. 121-111. All three of these are west of Sixth Ave., which is shown with.its elevated line thereon. This set of 2 views consists
of a negative and a positive.
1936.
W.P.A. Photo.

Seventh Ave., south from West 44th Street, and showing the southern portion of Times Square, with the Times Building separating Broadway from Seventh Ave. The buildings shown on the right (west side), and starting with the Paramont south to West 42nd Street, bear Broadway nunmbers,
but actually are on Seventh Ave.
1936.

723535f-a.text:
Broadway (Times Square), north from W. 44th Street. These W. P. A. photos are taken to show pavement conditions. The photographer's line of view is up 7th Avenue (which loses its identity between 42nd and 47th Streets); Broadway proper being on the right. These intersect at 45th Street. The Astor Hotel at the left, and the International Casino--Criterion Theatre Building at the right, occupy opposite frontages of the 44th
Street blocks.
June 4, 1937
Views 1,2
Works Progress Administration
Five Boroughs Project

713197f-b.text:
West 44th Street, north side, west from the Court, midway between Broadway and Eighth Ave. to the latter, showing in the foreground two theatres, the Shubert and the Majestic. The aforementioned Court, whose southern terminus appears on the right is located at the rear of the Astor Hotel and runs northward to 45th Street. The theatres bear street numbers 223 and 245 respectively. This set consists of a positive and
a negative vieW.
September 1935.

717497f-a.text:
Broadway (Times Square), east side, from West 44th (right) to 45th (left) Street's, showing the new theatre and taxpayer erected on the site of the oldd Criterion and the New York Theatre. Thts new structure houses a new Criterion Theatre and the International Casino. The Wrigley sign ab ve is quite distinctive and attracts great attention.
October 18, 1938
'eorge D Chinn

717499f-a.text:
The Criterion Theatre, Broadway at the N.E. corner of 44th Street. The building which houses the Criterion and New York theatres will be demolished in 1935, and in 1936 a new theatre will
be located on the site.
October 1, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
